column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|

#Text=Comparative analysis of genetic diversity in wild and restored subtropical rainforest trees:�Argyrodendron trifoliolatum,�Ficus watkinsiana, and�Diploglottis australis\rSally L Cooper,�Peter C Bundock,�Catherine Nock\rFirst published: 20 August 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14256\rAuthor contributions: SLC, PVB conceived and designed the research; SLC undertook the field work; SLC carried out the laboratory work; SLC, PCB, CN carried out the data analysis; SLC, PCB, CN wrote and edited the manuscript.
#Text=PCB is now retired.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Siegfried L.
#Text=Krauss\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Since European settlement of Australia, substantial areas of subtropical rainforest have been cleared.
#Text=More recently, effort is being made to restore areas of this ecological community.
#Text=The financial investment and increasing reliance on ecological restoration in biodiversity conservation justifies a need for better understanding of how to improve success at the genetic level.

#Text=This research measures genetic diversity (allelic richness [Rs], expected heterozygosity [He], and inbreeding using Wright's coefficient [FIS]) for expected neutral DNA markers in three Australian subtropical rainforest trees: White booyong (Argyrodendron trifoliolatum), Watkin's fig (Ficus watkinsiana), and Native tamarind (Diploglottis australis).
#Text=Wild and restored populations of these species were compared in two neighboring regions in Northeast New South Wales (the Tweed Caldera and the Big Scrub).
#Text=There were no statistically significant differences in Rs or He between wild and restored populations for any of the target species.
#Text=Inbreeding was significantly higher in one of the restored versus wild population comparisons: F. watkinsiana�in the Tweed (restored�F=0.20; wild�F=0.02;�p=0.01).

#Text=The comparable levels of genetic diversity observed in restored and wild populations targeted in this study are likely due to informed practitioner perspectives and practices, staged plantings over several years, and high genetic diversity and low genetic differentiation within source populations.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Restoration activities can influence the genetic composition of plant populations, sometimes creating populations that differ genetically from the local wild populations.\r* The risk of a reduction in genetic diversity in restored versus wild populations is expected to be less when source populations have high genetic diversity and low genetic differentiation.\r* Obtaining stock from large populations and multiple sources is a sensible safeguard to apply to all species to minimize the chance of introducing large numbers of highly inbred stock.\r* Staged restoration (multiple planting events) is likely to mitigate against losses in genetic diversity in restored populations by providing greater opportunity for the introduction of genetic variation and novel genetic combinations.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Compensatory restoration is increasingly relied upon for the persistence of ecological communities, especially where remnant communities are small, fragmented, and under threat of further degradation (Bull & Strange�2018).
#Text=Restoration often requires considerable financial outlay (Collard et al�2020).

#Text=Consequently, it can be prudent to study genetic diversity in restored and wild communities to inform future restoration efforts and better equip restoration plantings for survival into the future (Thomas et al�2014).

#Text=Assessing measurable indicators against predetermined goals and objectives is a key principle underpinning ecological restoration that allows for adaptive management and information sharing (Gann et al�2019).

#Text=Despite this, assessment of genetic indicators of restoration success is rarely employed due to the financial and time constraints involved and the specialist skills required for genetic research.
#Text=However, biodiversity encompasses all species and populations, including the genetic variation among them, as well as their complex assemblages of communities and ecosystems (CBD�2022).
#Text=Maintenance of genetic diversity in restored communities is a measure of fitness for a variety of ecological functions (Hughes et al�2008; Reynolds et al�2012; Kettenring et al�2014).

#Text=It is a significant determining factor to the long-term sustainability of a restored community (Kardos et al�2021) and is of importance and relevance to rainforest restoration practitioners, land managers, and the broader community (Cooper et al�2018).
#Text=A wholistic assessment of ecological restoration success should include analysis of genetic diversity, where possible.
#Text=Ecological restoration typically takes place in landscapes that have been subject to large-scale habitat clearing and fragmentation.

#Text=Remnant populations in these types of landscapes face genetic pressures such as lower mate availability and restrictions to gene flow, which can lead to decreased genetic diversity, increased population differentiation, and elevated inbreeding (Lowe et al�2004).

#Text=Fragmentation and a reduction in flowering-tree density can affect plant mating systems through increased self-pollination and breeding between related individuals, leading to increasingly inbred populations (Konuma et al�2000; Breed et al�2013).
#Text=In outbreeding species, inbreeding will typically reduce fitness.

#Text=This is due to an increase in the proportion of homozygous loci, which in turn increases the chance of expression of rare deleterious recessive alleles, which are usually masked by heterozygosity.

#Text=This is especially the case with progeny resulting from self-fertilization, where there is a 25% chance for each heterozygous deleterious recessive allele in the parent to become homozygous (and therefore expressed) in each generation (Allendorf et al�2012).

#Text=Creating restored populations with germplasm collected from inbred individuals has the potential to affect the genetic fitness and the long-term viability of restored populations (Broadhurst�2011,�2013).

#Text=This research provides a comparison of genetic diversity and inbreeding between restored and wild populations for three subtropical rainforest tree species in Northeast New South Wales (NE NSW), Australia.
#Text=Genetic indicators including allelic richness (Rs), expected heterozygosity (He), and inbreeding using Wright's coefficient (FIS) were estimated using expected neutral DNA markers.
#Text=The hypothesis tested was that there is a reduction in genetic diversity for restored rainforest tree species relative to those from wild populations.
#Text=The null hypothesis was that there is no difference in the genetic diversity of restored populations relative to wild populations.

#Text=A secondary question was,  Are trees in restored populations more inbred than those in the wild reference populations� We also assessed genetic differentiation (FST) of wild populations from two neighboring geographic regions within NE NSW.
#Text=Methods.

#Text=Site Selection and Leaf Sample Collection\rThe two study regions comprise the Big Scrub area of the Richmond River catchment ( 28.602/153.251;  28.911/153.551) and the Tweed area of the Tweed River catchment ( 28.158/153.590;  28.544/153.120), which are situated on the far north coast of NSW, Australia (Fig�1).

#Text=Under the Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation for Australia (IBRA) classification system (version 7) (Thackway & Cresswell�1995), both study regions are within the South-East Queensland Bioregion.
#Text=Figure 1\rStudy area indicating the two regions of the Big Scrub and Tweed Caldera situated within the IBRA v7 South-East Queensland Bioregion.

#Text=The study regions are characterized by high rainfall (>1200 mm/year) and fertile volcanic soils, the combination of which has enabled the establishment of unique and diverse subtropical rainforest communities.

#Text=Large tracts were cleared with the introduction of colonial settlers, circa early to mid-1800s, with less than 1% of the pre-colonial settlement extent of the Big Scrub remaining (Parkes et al�2012).

#Text=Subtropical rainforest is now listed as a critically endangered ecosystem under the Commonwealth�Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999�(EPBC Act) and an endangered ecosystem under the NSW�Biodiversity Conservation Act 2016.
#Text=Despite extensive clearing throughout both study regions, remnant patches of subtropical rainforest persist (Parkes et al�2012).
#Text=More recently, effort has been made to restore rainforest in small areas on previously cleared land.
#Text=The three species targeted in this study were sampled from restored and wild communities within the Tweed and Big Scrub regions.
#Text=Restored subtropical rainforest in northern NSW is typically undertaken as small areas of plantings (often with components of assisted regeneration).

#Text=Within the study area, the size of the restored area from which planted samples were collected ranged from 0.9 to 16.0 ha, with a median size of 6.1ha, and often the plantings were in patches among remnant or regrowth native vegetation.
#Text=The restored sites were typically composed of numerous species to reflect the high species diversity characteristic of subtropical rainforest.

#Text=It became apparent early in this study that there were too few individuals of the target species at any single restoration site or wild site to collect sample sizes that would be meaningful in their own right.
#Text=Therefore, samples for each cohort were a composite of individuals collected from a variety of sites spread throughout the study regions (Table�S1; refer to Fig�1).
#Text=This approach ensured the restored population spanned a variety of different restoration sites and likely a mixture of different seed sources.
#Text=Individuals from the restored population included recent and advanced plantings ranging from approximately 1 year to more than 30 years old.
#Text=The size parameters of wild and restored individuals sampled are illustrated by diameter at breast height and height in Figure�S1.

#Text=The target sample size was 25 as, according to Hale et al (2012), 25_30 samples is considered adequate to represent allelic diversity of the population/cohort for population genetic studies using microsatellite loci.
#Text=This is consistent with the sample size recommended by Brown and Marshall (1995).
#Text=An average of 23 individuals were sampled, per species, per test community, and per region (minimum 21; maximum 25).

#Text=Target Species\rThe three subtropical rainforest species targeted in this study have varied mating and pollen/seed dispersal systems, which capture some of the variability employed by subtropical rainforest species.
#Text=�Ficus watkinsiana�occurs in two disjunct populations along the east coast of Australia (Fig�S2; Harden et al�2014; Atlas of Living Australia�2023a).

#Text=This species, which can be dioecious or monoecious, is wasp-pollinated with seed predominantly dispersed by medium to large frugivorous birds and flying foxes (Dixon�1999; Peel�2010; Williams & Adam�2010).

#Text=�Diploglottis australis�is distributed throughout the subtropical east coast of Australia and extending south into temperate climates in NSW, with a disjunct population recorded in tropical North Queensland (Fig�S2; Atlas of Living Australia�2023b).
#Text=Seed is primarily dispersed by birds and flying foxes (Peel�2010).
#Text=�Argyrodendron trifoliolatumis distributed throughout the subtropical and tropical east coast of Australia (Harden et al�2014).
#Text=A disjunct population is recorded in Papua New Guinea (Atlas of Living Australia�2023c) (Fig�S2).
#Text=Seed of this species is a samara adapted for wind dispersal.

#Text=Species-specific information on pollinators could not be found for�D. australis�or�A. trifoliolatum, however, these species are likely pollinated by a diverse guild of insect taxa, as is typical for most canopy species in subtropical rainforests of Australia (Williams & Adam�2010).
#Text=Pollen of these species is also likely dispersed by nectarivorous birds and flying foxes.
#Text=Information regarding the mating systems of these species was unavailable prior to this study.
#Text=DNA Extraction, Amplification, and Genotyping\rOnce collected, leaf samples were refrigerated and then frozen at  20degreesC for storage.

#Text=DNA was extracted using a variety of methods, including the cetyltrimethylammonium bromide-based method described by Xin and Chen (2012), QIAGEN DNeasy Plant Mini Kits, and Lucigen Epicenter QuickExtract DNA Extraction Solution.
#Text=Extracted DNA was quantified using a Qubit fluorometer.
#Text=The genetic analysis was undertaken using simple sequence repeats (SSR) markers, which were species-specific and developed for each of the three target species by Bottaro (2017).
#Text=Fluorescent labels were covalently attached to the forward primers for each SSR marker for analysis purposes.
#Text=Refer to Table�S2�for details on SSR markers and primers.
#Text=Samples were amplified using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and genotyped using capillary electrophoresis.

#Text=Of the microsatellites tested, those best performing were included in this study, amounting to seven, six, and four useable loci for�A. trifoliolatum,�F. watkinsiana, and�D. australis, respectively.
#Text=PCR testing and optimization were undertaken for each locus to determine the optimal conditions.

#Text=The 15  L PCR solution used comprised the following: sterile H2O (6.99  L),10   Platinum Buffer (1.5  L), 0.2 mM of combined deoxynucleotide triphosphate (0.24  L), 0.25  M fluorescently labeled forward (tagged with FAM, NED, PET, or VIC) and reverse primers (3  L), 0.08  g bovine serum albumin (0.12  L), 2 mM MgCl2�(0.6  L), 0.25 U platinum Taq (0.05  L), and DNA template (2.5  L).

#Text=PCRs were amplified on Applied Biosystems Veriti 96-Well Thermal Cyclers and Corbett Gradient Palm�Cyclers using the following generalized program: one cycle of 95degreesC for 2 minutes; 94degreesC for 20 seconds, 70degreesC for 30 seconds (with a touchdown of  1degreesC per cycle), 72degreesC for 1 minute for six cycles; followed by 94degreesC for 20 seconds, 56�62degreesC (depending on the locus) for 30 seconds, 72degreesC for 1 minute for 35 cycles; with a final 72degreesC for 5 minutes and 4degreesC hold at the completion of cycling.

#Text=Genotyping of amplified SSRs for each sample was outsourced to consultant Carlene Rooney and undertaken by capillary electrophoresis using an ABI PRISM 3730 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems Inc.).
#Text=Allele size was scored in reference to ABI PRISM GS (Liz) internal size standards using Geneious Prime version 2020.1.1 software.
#Text=Data Analysis\rThe presence of null alleles was tested using Micro-Checker v2.2.3 software (Van Oosterhout et al�2004).
#Text=Where null alleles were identified and accepted, corrections were applied using the  Brookfield 2� estimator (Brookfield�1996), as recommended by Girard and Angers (2008).
#Text=Genetic diversity measures were made on a total of 279 samples (21�25 leaf samples/cohort   3 species   2 treatment populations   2 regions).

#Text=Of these 279 samples, 94 were�A. trifoliolatum�(Big Scrub wild�n = 24, Big Scrub restored�n = 23, Tweed wild�n = 22, and Tweed restored�n = 25), 91 samples were�F. watkinsiana�(Big Scrub wild�n = 24, Big Scrub restored�n = 22, Tweed wild�n = 21, and Tweed restored�n = 24), and 94 samples were�D. australis�(Big Scrub wild�n = 24, Big Scrub restored�n = 24, Tweed wild�n = 24, and Tweed restored�n = 22).
#Text=Allelic richness (Rs), He, and a measure of inbreeding based on Wright's coefficient (FIS) were calculated for each SSR locus for the three tree species.

#Text=The number of alleles (Na), number of effective alleles (Ne), observed heterozygosity (Ho), He, and inbreeding coefficient (F) were calculated using GeneAlEx v6.503 (Peakall & Smouse�2006,�2012).

#Text=Rs and private allelic richness (Apr) were calculated using HP-Rare version 6 June 2006, which applied a rarefaction formula as described in Kalinowski (2004) to account for differing sample sizes.
#Text=Self-fertilization rates were estimated using robust multilocus estimate of selfing (RMES) software as described in David et al (2007).
#Text=A paired two-tailed�t-test was applied to each of the genetic diversity measures to compare between the control (wild) cohort and test (restored) cohort.

#Text=To investigate this relationship at a finer  site-based� scale, a comparison of genetic diversity indices between wild and restored individuals was also applied to a site within and adjacent to Durobby Nature Reserve in the Tweed using samples collected from within a 1 km radius (Site 4 in Table�S1).

#Text=Genetic differentiation between wild populations from the Big Scrub and Tweed regions was investigated using an analysis of molecular variance (AMOVA) assessment of the fixation indices (a measure of the proportion of shared alleles) implemented in GenAlEx v6.503 (Peakall & Smouse�2006,�2012) (permutations = 999, pairwise population permutations = 999).
#Text=Spatial autocorrelation was applied to look for any genetic structure patterns associated with geographic distance in each of the cohorts.
#Text=Spatial autocorrelation was undertaken using GenAlEx v6.503 (Peakall & Smouse�2006,�2012).

#Text=To compare the spatial genetic patterns of the populations observed in the Big Scrub and Tweed regions, the heterogeneity test (Omega) as described by Smouse et al (2008) (permutations�n = 999 and bootstrapping�n = 999) was applied.
#Text=The�p�value was set at 0.01 as recommended by Banks and Peakall (2012) to minimize the chance of type I errors (false positives).
#Text=Results.

#Text=Data Checking and Null Alleles\rAnalysis using Micro-Checker v2.2.3 software identified the potential presence of null alleles for both�Argyrodendron trifoliolatum�and�Diploglottis australis�due to heterozygosity deficits from Hardy�Weinberg equilibrium at certain loci.
#Text=Four of the seven loci analyzed for�A. trifoliolatum�were treated as containing null alleles (L1, L5, L10, and L11).
#Text=Two of the four loci analyzed for�D. australis�were treated as containing null alleles (L2 and L42).
#Text=There was no evidence of null alleles in�Ficus watkinsiana�samples.

#Text=For those loci assumed to be affected by null alleles, the allele frequencies were adjusted using the Brookfield 2 estimator (Brookfield�1996) in Micro-checker v2.2.3 (Van Oosterhout et al�2004).
#Text=Adjustments to error-prone loci are often necessary for downstream analyses in hypothesis testing to prevent biases in biological conclusions (Dewoody et al�2006).
#Text=No evidence of large allele dropout or scoring error due to stuttering was detected at any loci for any species, according to the Micro-Checker v2.2.3 analysis.
#Text=Null allele analysis is provided in Supplement�S1.
#Text=Self-Fertilization\rFor all populations, Ho values were equal to or within one standard error range of the He, based on data adjusted for null allele frequency estimates.
#Text=These values are indicative of populations that are achieving panmixia (random mating).
#Text=The exception was the restored Tweed�F. watkinsiana�population with Ho substantially lower than He and a high inbreeding coefficient (F = 0.20) (Table�1).
#Text=Table 1.

#Text=�Comparison of genetic diversity indices for wild and restored populations by species and region where�n = average sample size; Na = average no. of alleles; Ne = average no. of effective alleles; Rs = average allelic richness; Ho = average observed heterozygosity; He = average expected heterozygosity;�F = fixation index; Apr = private allelic richness;�s = self-fertilization rate as estimated by RMES (David et al�2007).
#Text=Statistically significant (p < 0.05) differences between wild and restored (Rest.) samples in each cohort are highlighted in bold.
#Text=Value in parentheses is SE.
#Text=Spp.
#Text=Region\rn\rNa\rNe\rRs\rHo\rHe\rF\rApr\rs\r\r\rWild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=Wild\rRest.
#Text=A moderate level of selfing was detected in the restored Tweed�F. watkinsiana�population (s = 0.26).
#Text=This suggests that the stock used at some of the restoration sites may be a product of self-fertilization, contributing to the relatively high inbreeding detected in this population (F = 0.20).
#Text=Selfing was not detected in the wild populations or the Big Scrub restored population for this species (s = 0) (Table�1).

#Text=Selfing analysis of�A. trifoliolatum�samples indicates moderate levels of self-fertilization occurring in the wild population in the Tweed (s = 0.21) and low levels in the wild population in the Big Scrub (s = 0.07).
#Text=A moderate level of selfing was also detected in the restored population in the Big Scrub (s = 0.22).
#Text=No self-fertilized individuals were detected in the Tweed restored population (s = 0) (Table�1).
#Text=Selfing analysis of�D. australis�samples identified low levels of self-fertilization in the wild populations (s = 0.08 in the Big Scrub and�s = 0.09 in the Tweed).
#Text=A higher level of selfing was identified in the restored population in the Tweed (s = 0.52), but no selfing was detected in the Big Scrub restored population for this species (s = 0) (Table�1).

#Text=Comparison of Genetic Diversity in Wild Versus Restored Populations\rThe data gathered from this study does not provide statistically significant evidence against the null hypothesis that genetic diversity is equivalent in restored versus wild populations of these subtropical rainforest tree species.
#Text=The genetic diversity results for each cohort were similar across both regions of the Tweed and Big Scrub.
#Text=Average Rs across all loci was higher in the wild populations compared with restored populations in five of the six comparisons within each species and region (Tables�1�&�S3�S5).
#Text=However, no statistically significant differences in Rs or He were detected in any of the comparisons.

#Text=The only statistically significant differences detected relate to the Tweed restored population, which had significantly higher Ho (p = 0.037), a significantly higher inbreeding coefficient (F,�p = 0.010), and significantly higher Apr (p = 0.008) (Table�1).
#Text=In the case of�A. trifoliolatum, the Rs and He of the restored population were lower than that of the wild population in the Big Scrub.
#Text=While this difference was not significant at�p�greater than 0.05, it was at the 0.1 level (Rs,�p = 0.079, He�p = 0.068).
#Text=No significant difference in Rs or He was detected for this species in the Tweed (Rs,�p = 0.289; He,�p = 0.882).

#Text=For�F. watkinsiana, the difference in Rs and He between the wild and restored populations was not significant in the Big Scrub (Rs,�p = 0.505 and He,�p = 0.707), or the Tweed (Rs,�p = 0.377 and He,�p = 0.282).

#Text=For�D. australis, there was no significant difference between the wild and restored populations for these metrics in either the Big Scrub (Rs,�p = 0.737 and He,�p = 0.826), or the Tweed (Rs,�p = 0.378 and He,�p = 0.533).
#Text=Allelic richness and He results for all restored populations were at least 80 and 90%, respectively, of that recorded in the corresponding wild reference populations.
#Text=Differences in genetic diversity between wild and restored populations were not strongly correlated with a particular species as no difference was found to be significant.

#Text=When examined at a site-based scale using wild (n = 8) and restored (n = 6) individuals of�F. watkinsiana�collected from within a 1 km radius, a statistically significant reduction in He was detected in the restored cohort (He,�p = 0.026).
#Text=No significant differences were detected in Rs (p = 0.396), Apr (p = 0.427), Ho (p = 0.698) or the inbreeding coefficient (F,�p = 0.191) for this site-based comparison.
#Text=No other sites had sufficient numbers of wild and restored individuals of the same species to test this comparison at the site-scale.

#Text=With regards to the secondary hypothesis that inbred individuals would be more common in restored compared to wild communities, the inbreeding coefficient was found to be significantly higher (p = 0.01) in the restored Tweed�F. watkinsiana�population (F = 0.20) compared to the wild population (F =  0.02) in that region.

#Text=This was associated with a significant difference in Ho (p = 0.037) due to three highly homozygous individuals, which were probably the result of self-pollinations (s = 0.26 for this population).
#Text=When an estimate of the rate of selfing for this population was carried out after excluding these three individuals, the rate was estimated to be zero (s = 0).
#Text=No detectable differences in inbreeding levels were identified in the Big Scrub�F. watkinsiana�populations or in the other species�A. trifoliolatum�and�D. australis�in either region.

#Text=Genetic Differentiation Between Regions\rResults from the AMOVA assessment of fixation indices found most molecular variance occurred within individuals (91, 87, and 86% for�F. watkinsiana,�A. trifoliolatum, and�D. australis, respectively).
#Text=A relatively small proportion of variance was found between individuals (�12%) and even less between populations (�3%).
#Text=No molecular variance was detected between regions (0% for all species).

#Text=No statistically significant genetic differentiation was found between Big Scrub and Tweed wild populations for any of the species tested (A. trifoliolatum:�  = 0.003;�p = 0.259;�F. watkinsiana:�  = 0.001;�p = 0.389;�D. australis:�  = 0.006;�p = 0.088) (Tables�S6�S8).

#Text=Population Genetic Structure\rThe spatial autocorrelation test found no significant autocorrelation between genetic and geographic distance within wild populations of�A. trifoliolatum�at any of the distance classes tested (1, 1.3, 20, and 31 km) in either region (Tweed:�r  0.013 to 0.018,�p > 0.01; Big Scrub:�r 0.019 to 0.022,�p > 0.01).

#Text=The results of the heterogeneity test suggest no regional difference in this pattern (or lack of spatial genetic structure) between the Tweed and Big Scrub wild populations of�A. trifoliolatum�(total�  = 2.085;�p = 0.862).

#Text=Similarly, no autocorrelation between genetic and geographic distance was detected within wild populations of�F. watkinsiana�at any of the distance classes tested (1.9, 19, 29, and 39 km) (Tweed:�r� 0.019 to 0.017,�p > 0.01; Big Scrub:�r� 0.015 to 0.022;�p > 0.01).
#Text=No regional difference in this pattern was detected between the Big Scrub and Tweed regions for wild populations of�F. watkinsiana�(total�  = 2.614;�p = 0.731).
#Text=Results of the spatial autocorrelation test did detect a statistically significant though weak autocorrelation between genetic and geographic distance within wild populations of�D. australis.

#Text=In the Big Scrub region, a significant correlation was detected at the 1 km distance class (r = 0.054,�p = 0.002) and at the 35 km distance class (r =  0.028,�p = 0.009), though none of the other distance classes tested (15 or 22 km) produced significant autocorrelations.

#Text=In the Tweed, significant autocorrelation was detected at the 1 km (r = 0.077,�p = 0.002), 15 km (r =  0.030,�p = 0.005), and 22 km (r =  0.065,�p = 0.005) distance classes, with no correlation detected at the 35 km distance class.

#Text=There were no consistent structuring patterns detected between the regions, with the heterogeneity test identifying weak but statistically significant heterogeneity between Tweed and Big Scrub wild populations of�D. australis�(total�  = 9.281;�p = 0.016).
#Text=Refer to Figures�S3�S5�for correlograms.
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=Genetic Diversity and Inbreeding\rThe genetic analysis results of the three target species,�Argyrodendron trifoliolatum,�Ficus watkinsiana,�and Diploglottis australis, are indicative of high within-population genetic variability when compared to genetic diversity data reported for other Australian subtropical rainforest trees, including�Elaeocarpus grandis�(mean�A = 3.4, mean He = 0.568) sampled across the southern portion of the species distribution (Rossetto et al�2004),�Macadamia tetraphylla�(mean�A = 4.602, mean He = 0.512) (O'Connor et al�2015) and�Podocarpus elatus(mean�A = 5.000, mean He = 0.528) (Mellick et al�2011).

#Text=Levels of genetic diversity reported for Australian cool temperate rainforest tree�Nothofagus moorei�(mean�A = 8.136, mean He = 0.728) (Shultz�2008) and warm temperate rainforest tree�Ceratopetalum apetalum�(mean�A = 6.851, mean He = 0.681) (Heslewood et al�2014) are higher than the aforementioned subtropical rainforest tree species but still lower than that detected for the study species.

#Text=Genetic diversity levels reported for pioneer South East Asian tropical rainforest species�Macaranga beccariana�(mean�A = 4.88, mean He = 0.628), and�M. hypoleuca�(mean�A = 4.66, mean He = 0.692) (Guicking et al�2013) show a lower average number of alleles per locus but comparable levels of He.

#Text=Research on the widespread Southeast Asian lowland tropical rainforest tree�Shorea parviflora�has reported comparably high levels of genetic diversity to the study species (mean�A = 15.45, mean He = 0.773) (Widiyatno et al�2016).
#Text=The variability in the genetic diversity results among the studied rainforest trees is likely a combination of multiple factors.

#Text=Some generalized patterns reported include Australian rainforest trees with an Indo-Malesian (Sunda) lineage typically exhibiting lower genetic diversity than those with a Gondwana (Sahul) lineage with longer local histories (Rossetto et al�2015).
#Text=Other attributes displaying positive correlations with genetic diversity (He) include range size, growth form, abundance, and biome (Broadhurst et al�2017).

#Text=Species that are widespread typically have higher genetic diversity than those with regional or localized ranges, species with semi-continuous abundance have higher genetic diversity than those with patchy abundance, trees have higher genetic diversity than shrubs and herbs, and species located in the east coast biome of Australia have higher genetic diversity than those from the west and tropical biomes (Broadhurst et al�2017).

#Text=This study also found that Australian taxa was typically comparable to global estimates of genetic diversity, with the exception of widespread species, for which Australian species had higher genetic diversity (He = 0.70) than global estimates (He = 0.62) (Broadhurst et al�2017).

#Text=The subtropical rainforest species studied in this research,�A. trifoliolatum,�F. watkinsiana, and�D. australis, are all trees that are widespread, with semi-continuous abundance within the east coast biome of Australia.

#Text=The sampling strategy for this study, which was confined to a small area relative to the total species range, may be inflating the high genetic diversity results, if the study area represents an area of higher genetic diversity compared to elsewhere throughout the species range.
#Text=The hypothesis that inbred individuals would be more common in restored compared to wild communities was supported by one comparison in the Tweed (F. watkinsiana).

#Text=The restored Tweed�F. watkinsiana�populations combination of a high inbreeding coefficient coupled with high genetic diversity has been reported in other restored populations, including those established from multiple genetic founders, with population sizes equivalent to native populations and a positive growth rate (Salas-Leiva et al�2009; Fant et al�2013).
#Text=The high inbreeding coefficients in these genetically diverse restored populations were attributed to either true inbreeding or a restoration-induced Wahlund effect (Wahlund�1928).

#Text=In this study, a Wahlund effect could have potentially been created if genetically distinct seed sources (seed from different subpopulations) had been sampled across the different collection sites.
#Text=However, this sampling strategy was employed across all populations, and only one was found to exhibit inbreeding.
#Text=The results of the AMOVA assessment of the fixation indices and the spatial autocorrelation test are not suggestive of genetic structuring within the study area.
#Text=The evidence of selfing in a single Tweed�F. watkinsiana�population and lack of evidence of structuring among samples suggest that this may be the result of true inbreeding.
#Text=However, sampling throughout the species full distribution and a better understanding of spatial genetic differentiation relative to the sampling strategy would add clarity to this assertion.
#Text=Seed collection decisions have the potential to impact the genetic health of restored populations.

#Text=The more inbred individuals are deployed to a restoration site, the greater the chance of deleterious alleles being expressed with potentially unfavorable ecological outcomes (e.g. lower fecundity and disease resistance).
#Text=Individuals may self-fertilize for reproductive assurance in response to a lack of pollinators and/or mates (Barrett�2013).

#Text=While monoecious�F. watkinsiana�trees are self-compatible, the lack of evidence for trees resulting from self-pollination in the wild populations suggests that there may be selective pressures toward a preferentially outcrossing mixed mating system in this species or that progeny created from self-fertilization have been selected against prior to reaching maturity.

#Text=Similarly, the low levels of selfing detected in wild populations of�D. australis�and moderate levels detected in wild populations of�A. trifoliolatum�suggest these species are self-compatible but more commonly the result of outcrossing, likely because of selective pressure toward outcrossing.

#Text=Evidence of selection against selfed progeny has been previously reported in tree species at various stages of their lifecycle, including embryo, seedling, and sapling stages (Hufford & Hamrick�2003; Naito et al�2005; Williams�2008).

#Text=Possible reasons for observed losses of selfed individuals as they progress through their life cycle include smaller seed mass (Hufford & Hamrick�2003; Naito et al�2005) and expression of deleterious recessive alleles (Kuang et al�1998).

#Text=Seed collectors could assist in minimizing the chance of collecting selfed seed by limiting collection from highly isolated trees, such as paddock trees, despite their appeal due to ease of collection.

#Text=Given the unknown factors regarding the mating system of many species employed in restoration works, obtaining stock from large populations and multiple sources is a sensible safeguard to apply to all species to minimize the chance of introducing large numbers of highly inbred stock (Harrison et al�2021; SERA�2021).

#Text=Are Restored Populations Capturing the Genetic Diversity of Their Wild Reference Populations \rThis study suggests that the restored subtropical tree populations substantially match the genetic diversity of their wild source populations.

#Text=Large and significant reductions in genetic diversity (akin to founder events) in the restored populations were not observed in this study, as they have been in others, for example Salas-Leiva et al (2009).

#Text=Previous comparative analyses of this kind have produced variable results, with the number of studies providing evidence for reductions in genetic diversity in restored populations only marginally higher than those providing evidence for increases in genetic diversity in restored populations (Jordan et al�2019).

#Text=According to Jordan et al (2019), studies reporting higher levels of genetic diversity in revegetation compared to natural stands were more likely to have been established using multiple seed sources, whereas those that found reduced levels of genetic diversity in revegetation than in natural stands were more likely to have been sourced from a single site.
#Text=The seed sources used to establish the restored populations studied here are unknown.

#Text=It is possible that the seedlings utilized in the Tweed and Big Scrub restoration projects originate from beyond these regions, as the range of occurrence of all three target species extends considerably further.

#Text=The introduction of propagules from much greater distances (e.g. the northern or southern extents of the range or, in the case of�D. australis�and�A. trifoliolatum, from the northern disjunct parts of their range) may be contributing to elevated levels of genetic diversity.
#Text=One of the nurseries operating in the region indicated they accept seed from throughout Australia (Bottaro�2017).
#Text=It is known that seed collectors and native nursery workers operating in these regions value the importance of genetic diversity in ecological restoration (Cooper et al�2018).

#Text=In a survey that asked these seed collectors and native nursery workers for the most effective approach to increasing genetic diversity in restored rainforest communities, the following response was most favored:  obtaining seed from more than one remnant patch� (Cooper et al�2018).

#Text=This awareness of the importance of maximizing genetic diversity in ecological restoration and an understanding of the importance of collecting from multiple sites may have contributed to the results of this study that suggest genetic diversity has been maintained in restored populations.

#Text=The combination of the apparent intrinsically high within-population genetic diversity of the studied species, the lack of strong genetic differentiation throughout the study regions, as well as the logistical and financial necessity of creating the restored population from numerous plantings staged over several years, may inadvertently limit losses in genetic diversity.

#Text=However, it is acknowledged that the conclusion that these restored populations are comparable to the wild populations, in terms of genetic diversity, assumes that the various restoration sites collectively making up the restored population are capable of interbreeding.
#Text=That is, it is assumed they are not genetically isolated from one another and are in fact operating as a true population.
#Text=Considering the pollination and seed dispersal mechanisms of these species, gene flow between individuals throughout each of the study regions is considered plausible.

#Text=However,�A. trifoliolatum�would be expected to have the greatest challenge to region-wide genetic exchange on account of its wind seed dispersal (Lowe et al�2018) and would likely depend on pollen mediated gene flow (Heslewood et al�2014).

#Text=The finer scale site-based comparison of genetic diversity metrics in�F. watkinsianademonstrated a statistically significant reduction in He but no statistically significant changes in the other genetic diversity metrics tested.
#Text=While Rs was not significantly different between the wild and restored cohorts at this site, the frequency of this comparable number of alleles was, as reflected by the difference in He.
#Text=The reduction in He may indicate the less frequent alleles are at risk of being lost in future generations of restored individuals.
#Text=However, this would only be true if gene flow between the restored and wild individuals is restricted or severed.

#Text=Given the proximity of the restored individuals to the wild individuals at this site (within a 1 km radius) and its highly mobile pollinators, gene flow is expected to persist, and the opportunity for the allele frequency of the restored individual's offspring to better reflect that of the wild cohort remains.
#Text=The spatial autocorrelation results support this assumption, with no strong correlation between genetic and geographic distances detected for�F. watkinsiana.

#Text=Genetic Differentiation Between Regions\rThe lack of molecular variance, genetic differentiation, or strong autocorrelation between genetic and geographic distance detected between wild populations from the Big Scrub and Tweed region suggests that there has been genetic connectedness, at least in the relatively recent past, due to gene flow between these two neighboring regions.

#Text=These results suggest that the local genetic neighborhood for these three species of subtropical rainforest trees may encompass both regions of the Tweed and Big Scrub, spanning at least 80 km within NE NSW.

#Text=This distance of genetic neighborhood is consistent in scale with the Zucchi et al (2018) study of four tropical semi-deciduous species, which found distinct gene pools in wild individuals occurring greater than 250 km away.

#Text=Similarly, no population differentiation was found in Australian rainforest trees from the�Elaeocarpus�genus in Northern NSW across the study area, which extended approximately 250 km (Rossetto et al�2004).

#Text=The Restore and Renew webtool (The Royal Botanic Garden�2021) estimates a local seed collection zone for various species based on genetic information, species distribution ranges, and climate models.
#Text=One of the target species from this study�D. australis�is addressed by this resource.

#Text=For this species, the local seed collection zone, based on a site located in NE NSW (both Murwillumbah and Lismore were investigated), spans approximately 315�350 km north to south and 163�192 km east to west.

#Text=This result suggests that the statistical significance detected for the spatial autocorrelation result for�D. australis�is unlikely representative of true population structuring, at least not at a landscape scale.

#Text=Finer scale and systematic sampling throughout the species ranges would improve the reliability of spatial autocorrelation testing in describing population genetic structuring for these species.

#Text=Rainforest species with highly mobile seed dispersal vectors and a history of broadscale connected habitat are expected to have more extensive local genetic neighborhoods than species from different habitats, which have been historically isolated.

#Text=Propagules of�A. trifoliolatum,�F. watkinsiana, and�D. australis�sourced from anywhere within the neighboring regions of the Tweed and Big Scrub would be considered suitable for use in revegetation projects within these regions.
#Text=Incorporating propagules or seedlings sourced from multiple sources will assist in minimizing the chance of collecting a high proportion of inbred individuals.

#Text=Propagules of mixed source may follow any of the established provenancing strategies described, including  composite provenancing� (Broadhurst et al�2008) (mixing seed from healthy local populations with smaller amounts of seed from more distant populations),  admixture provenancing� (Breed et al�2013) (mixing seed sourced from a wide array of provenances with no spatial bias toward the revegetation site),  regional admixture provenancing� (Bucharova et al�2019) (mixing of seed from several populations located within a defined bioregion).
#Text=These approaches are expected to provide the broadest genetic base to allow natural selection, mutation, and recombination to act upon.
#Text=Further research into gene flow between the restored patches and between restored and wild patches would provide further insights to the results presented here.

#Text=Furthermore, research on the genetic diversity of natural recruits within these populations would yield valuable information on the levels of genetic diversity and inbreeding over successive generations.
